p: Mutations in several genes can cause rare syndromes of a more complex phenotype with parkinsonism representing only one of several clinical features. Some of them have been designated as “PARK”-genes ( ATP13A2 - PARK9, PLA2G6 - PARK14 and FXBOX - PARK15), but others have not (e.g. DCTN1, responsible for Perry syndrome, or MAPT or PRGN, which cause frontotemporal dementia (FTD), which can occur with or without parkinsonism). Even elongated repeat expansions in the SCA2 gene have been described in patients with parkinsonism and no overt ataxia [ 28].
